byline.contributor: Nikita Stewart contributed reporting from Johns Island, S.C.; Frances Robles from Columbia, S.C.; and Ashley Southall from New York.
byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and RICHARD FAUSSET

abstract: Emanuel AME Church in Charleston, SC, opens its doors for regular Sunday service just four days after bloody massacre that claimed nine lives; decision is in line with history of courageous defiance at church that dates to antebellum era; service is flooded with churchgoers who are eager to display their unity and show that massacre would not succeed in setting off race war as shooter apparently intended.
lead_paragraph: A diverse gathering of mourners crowded beneath Emanuel A.M.E. Church’s vaulted barrel roof days after nine black churchgoers were killed in an attack.

headline.main: Defiant Show of Unity in Charleston Church That Lost 9 to Racist Violence
headline.print_headline: Defiant Show of Unity in Church That Lost 9 to Racial Violence

snippet: A diverse gathering of mourners crowded beneath Emanuel A.M.E. Church’s vaulted barrel roof days after nine black churchgoers were killed in an attack.

keywords.value: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church (Charleston, SC)
keywords.name: organizations
